1.text: The words of the Preacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem.

2.text: Vanity of vanities, saith the Preacher, vanity of vanities! all is vanity.

3.text: What profit hath man of all his labour wherewith he laboureth under the sun?

4.text: [One] generation passeth away, and [another] generation cometh, but the earth standeth for ever.

5.text: The sun also riseth, and the sun goeth down, and hasteth to its place where it ariseth.

6.text: The wind goeth towards the south, and turneth about towards the north: it turneth about continually, and the wind returneth again to its circuits.

7.text: All the rivers run into the sea, yet the sea is not full: unto the place whither the rivers go, thither they go again.

8.text: All things are full of toil; none can express it. The eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing.

9.text: That which hath been is that which shall be; and that which hath been done is that which will be done: and there is nothing new under the sun.

10.text: Is there a thing whereof it may be said, See, this is new? It hath been already in the ages which were before us.

11.text: There is no remembrance of former things; neither shall there be remembrance of things that are to come with those who shall live afterwards.

12.text: I, the Preacher, was king over Israel in Jerusalem.

13.text: And I applied my heart to seek and search out by wisdom concerning all that is done under the heavens: this grievous occupation hath God given to the children of men to weary themselves therewith.

14.text: I have seen all the works that are done under the sun, and behold, all is vanity and pursuit of the wind.

15.text: That which is crooked cannot be made straight; and that which is wanting cannot be numbered.

16.text: I communed with mine own heart, saying, Lo, I have become great and have acquired wisdom more than all they that have been before me over Jerusalem; and my heart hath seen much of wisdom and knowledge.

17.text: And I applied my heart to the knowledge of wisdom, and to the knowledge of madness and folly: I perceived that this also is a striving after the wind.

18.text: For in much wisdom is much vexation, and he that increaseth knowledge increaseth sorrow.
